00059 #ifndef HEADER_ENGINE_H
00060 #define HEADER_ENGINE_H
00061 
00062 #include <openssl/opensslconf.h>
00063 
00064 #ifdef OPENSSL_NO_ENGINE
00065 #error ENGINE is disabled.
00066 #endif
00067 
00068 #include <openssl/ossl_typ.h>
00069 #include <openssl/bn.h>
00070 #ifndef OPENSSL_NO_RSA
00071 #include <openssl/rsa.h>
00072 #endif
00073 #ifndef OPENSSL_NO_DSA
00074 #include <openssl/dsa.h>
00075 #endif
00076 #ifndef OPENSSL_NO_DH
00077 #include <openssl/dh.h>
00078 #endif
00079 #include <openssl/rand.h>
00080 #include <openssl/ui.h>
00081 #include <openssl/symhacks.h>
00082 #include <openssl/err.h>

00084 #ifdef  __cplusplus
00085 extern "C" {
00086 #endif
00087 
00088 /* Fixups for missing algorithms */
00089 #ifdef OPENSSL_NO_RSA
00090 typedef void RSA_METHOD;
00091 #endif
00092 #ifdef OPENSSL_NO_DSA
00093 typedef void DSA_METHOD;
00094 #endif
00095 #ifdef OPENSSL_NO_DH
00096 typedef void DH_METHOD;
00097 #endif
00098 
00099 /* These flags are used to control combinations of algorithm (methods)
00100  * by bitwise "OR"ing. */
00101 #define ENGINE_METHOD_RSA       (unsigned int)0x0001
00102 #define ENGINE_METHOD_DSA       (unsigned int)0x0002
00103 #define ENGINE_METHOD_DH        (unsigned int)0x0004
00104 #define ENGINE_METHOD_RAND      (unsigned int)0x0008
00105 #define ENGINE_METHOD_CIPHERS       (unsigned int)0x0040
00106 #define ENGINE_METHOD_DIGESTS       (unsigned int)0x0080
00107 /* Obvious all-or-nothing cases. */
00108 #define ENGINE_METHOD_ALL       (unsigned int)0xFFFF
00109 #define ENGINE_METHOD_NONE      (unsigned int)0x0000
00110 
00111 /* This(ese) flag(s) controls behaviour of the ENGINE_TABLE mechanism used
00112  * internally to control registration of ENGINE implementations, and can be set
00113  * by ENGINE_set_table_flags(). The "NOINIT" flag prevents attempts to
00114  * initialise registered ENGINEs if they are not already initialised. */
00115 #define ENGINE_TABLE_FLAG_NOINIT    (unsigned int)0x0001
00116 
00117 /* ENGINE flags that can be set by ENGINE_set_flags(). */
00118 /* #define ENGINE_FLAGS_MALLOCED    0x0001 */ /* Not used */
00119 
00120 /* This flag is for ENGINEs that wish to handle the various 'CMD'-related
00121  * control commands on their own. Without this flag, ENGINE_ctrl() handles these
00122  * control commands on behalf of the ENGINE using their "cmd_defns" data. */
00123 #define ENGINE_FLAGS_MANUAL_CMD_CTRL    (int)0x0002
00124 
00125 /* This flag is for ENGINEs who return new duplicate structures when found via
00126  * "ENGINE_by_id()". When an ENGINE must store state (eg. if ENGINE_ctrl()
00127  * commands are called in sequence as part of some stateful process like
00128  * key-generation setup and execution), it can set this flag - then each attempt
00129  * to obtain the ENGINE will result in it being copied into a new structure.
00130  * Normally, ENGINEs don't declare this flag so ENGINE_by_id() just increments
00131  * the existing ENGINE's structural reference count. */
00132 #define ENGINE_FLAGS_BY_ID_COPY     (int)0x0004
00133 
00134 /* ENGINEs can support their own command types, and these flags are used in
00135  * ENGINE_CTRL_GET_CMD_FLAGS to indicate to the caller what kind of input each
00136  * command expects. Currently only numeric and string input is supported. If a
00137  * control command supports none of the _NUMERIC, _STRING, or _NO_INPUT options,
00138  * then it is regarded as an "internal" control command - and not for use in
00139  * config setting situations. As such, they're not available to the
00140  * ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string() function, only raw ENGINE_ctrl() access. Changes to
00141  * this list of 'command types' should be reflected carefully in
00142  * ENGINE_cmd_is_executable() and ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string(). */
00143 
00144 /* accepts a 'long' input value (3rd parameter to ENGINE_ctrl) */
00145 #define ENGINE_CMD_FLAG_NUMERIC     (unsigned int)0x0001
00146 /* accepts string input (cast from 'void*' to 'const char *', 4th parameter to
00147  * ENGINE_ctrl) */
00148 #define ENGINE_CMD_FLAG_STRING      (unsigned int)0x0002
00149 /* Indicates that the control command takes *no* input. Ie. the control command
00150  * is unparameterised. */
00151 #define ENGINE_CMD_FLAG_NO_INPUT    (unsigned int)0x0004
00152 /* Indicates that the control command is internal. This control command won't
00153  * be shown in any output, and is only usable through the ENGINE_ctrl_cmd()
00154  * function. */
00155 #define ENGINE_CMD_FLAG_INTERNAL    (unsigned int)0x0008
00156 
00157 /* NB: These 3 control commands are deprecated and should not be used. ENGINEs
00158  * relying on these commands should compile conditional support for
00159  * compatibility (eg. if these symbols are defined) but should also migrate the
00160  * same functionality to their own ENGINE-specific control functions that can be
00161  * "discovered" by calling applications. The fact these control commands
00162  * wouldn't be "executable" (ie. usable by text-based config) doesn't change the
00163  * fact that application code can find and use them without requiring per-ENGINE
00164  * hacking. */
00165 
00166 /* These flags are used to tell the ctrl function what should be done.
00167  * All command numbers are shared between all engines, even if some don't
00168  * make sense to some engines.  In such a case, they do nothing but return
00169  * the error ENGINE_R_CTRL_COMMAND_NOT_IMPLEMENTED. */
00170 #define ENGINE_CTRL_SET_LOGSTREAM       1
00171 #define ENGINE_CTRL_SET_PASSWORD_CALLBACK   2
00172 #define ENGINE_CTRL_HUP             3 /* Close and reinitialise any
00173                              handles/connections etc. */
00174 #define ENGINE_CTRL_SET_USER_INTERFACE          4 /* Alternative to callback */
00175 #define ENGINE_CTRL_SET_CALLBACK_DATA           5 /* User-specific data, used
00176                                                      when calling the password
00177                                                      callback and the user
00178                                                      interface */
00179 
00180 /* These control commands allow an application to deal with an arbitrary engine
00181  * in a dynamic way. Warn: Negative return values indicate errors FOR THESE
00182  * COMMANDS because zero is used to indicate 'end-of-list'. Other commands,
00183  * including ENGINE-specific command types, return zero for an error.
00184  *
00185  * An ENGINE can choose to implement these ctrl functions, and can internally
00186  * manage things however it chooses - it does so by setting the
00187  * ENGINE_FLAGS_MANUAL_CMD_CTRL flag (using ENGINE_set_flags()). Otherwise the
00188  * ENGINE_ctrl() code handles this on the ENGINE's behalf using the cmd_defns
00189  * data (set using ENGINE_set_cmd_defns()). This means an ENGINE's ctrl()
00190  * handler need only implement its own commands - the above "meta" commands will
00191  * be taken care of. */
00192 
00193 /* Returns non-zero if the supplied ENGINE has a ctrl() handler. If "not", then
00194  * all the remaining control commands will return failure, so it is worth
00195  * checking this first if the caller is trying to "discover" the engine's
00196  * capabilities and doesn't want errors generated unnecessarily. */
00197 #define ENGINE_CTRL_HAS_CTRL_FUNCTION       10
00198 /* Returns a positive command number for the first command supported by the
00199  * engine. Returns zero if no ctrl commands are supported. */
00200 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_FIRST_CMD_TYPE      11
00201 /* The 'long' argument specifies a command implemented by the engine, and the
00202  * return value is the next command supported, or zero if there are no more. */
00203 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_NEXT_CMD_TYPE       12
00204 /* The 'void*' argument is a command name (cast from 'const char *'), and the
00205  * return value is the command that corresponds to it. */
00206 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_CMD_FROM_NAME       13
00207 /* The next two allow a command to be converted into its corresponding string
00208  * form. In each case, the 'long' argument supplies the command. In the NAME_LEN
00209  * case, the return value is the length of the command name (not counting a
00210  * trailing EOL). In the NAME case, the 'void*' argument must be a string buffer
00211  * large enough, and it will be populated with the name of the command (WITH a
00212  * trailing EOL). */
00213 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_NAME_LEN_FROM_CMD   14
00214 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_NAME_FROM_CMD       15
00215 /* The next two are similar but give a "short description" of a command. */
00216 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_DESC_LEN_FROM_CMD   16
00217 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_DESC_FROM_CMD       17
00218 /* With this command, the return value is the OR'd combination of
00219  * ENGINE_CMD_FLAG_*** values that indicate what kind of input a given
00220  * engine-specific ctrl command expects. */
00221 #define ENGINE_CTRL_GET_CMD_FLAGS       18
00222 
00223 /* ENGINE implementations should start the numbering of their own control
00224  * commands from this value. (ie. ENGINE_CMD_BASE, ENGINE_CMD_BASE + 1, etc). */
00225 #define ENGINE_CMD_BASE     200
00226 
00227 /* NB: These 2 nCipher "chil" control commands are deprecated, and their
00228  * functionality is now available through ENGINE-specific control commands
00229  * (exposed through the above-mentioned 'CMD'-handling). Code using these 2
00230  * commands should be migrated to the more general command handling before these
00231  * are removed. */
00232 
00233 /* Flags specific to the nCipher "chil" engine */
00234 #define ENGINE_CTRL_CHIL_SET_FORKCHECK      100
00235     /* Depending on the value of the (long)i argument, this sets or
00236      * unsets the SimpleForkCheck flag in the CHIL API to enable or
00237      * disable checking and workarounds for applications that fork().
00238      */
00239 #define ENGINE_CTRL_CHIL_NO_LOCKING     101
00240     /* This prevents the initialisation function from providing mutex
00241      * callbacks to the nCipher library. */
00242 
00243 /* If an ENGINE supports its own specific control commands and wishes the
00244  * framework to handle the above 'ENGINE_CMD_***'-manipulation commands on its
00245  * behalf, it should supply a null-terminated array of ENGINE_CMD_DEFN entries
00246  * to ENGINE_set_cmd_defns(). It should also implement a ctrl() handler that
00247  * supports the stated commands (ie. the "cmd_num" entries as described by the
00248  * array). NB: The array must be ordered in increasing order of cmd_num.
00249  * "null-terminated" means that the last ENGINE_CMD_DEFN element has cmd_num set
00250  * to zero and/or cmd_name set to NULL. */
00251 typedef struct ENGINE_CMD_DEFN_st
00252     {
00253     unsigned int cmd_num; /* The command number */
00254     const char *cmd_name; /* The command name itself */
00255     const char *cmd_desc; /* A short description of the command */
00256     unsigned int cmd_flags; /* The input the command expects */
00257     } ENGINE_CMD_DEFN;
00258 
00259 /* Generic function pointer */
00260 typedef int (*ENGINE_GEN_FUNC_PTR)();
00261 /* Generic function pointer taking no arguments */
00262 typedef int (*ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR)(ENGINE *);
00263 /* Specific control function pointer */
00264 typedef int (*ENGINE_CTRL_FUNC_PTR)(ENGINE *, int, long, void *, void (*f)());
00265 /* Generic load_key function pointer */
00266 typedef EVP_PKEY * (*ENGINE_LOAD_KEY_PTR)(ENGINE *, const char *,
00267     UI_METHOD *ui_method, void *callback_data);
00268 /* These callback types are for an ENGINE's handler for cipher and digest logic.
00269  * These handlers have these prototypes;
00270  *   int foo(ENGINE *e, const EVP_CIPHER **cipher, const int **nids, int nid);
00271  *   int foo(ENGINE *e, const EVP_MD **digest, const int **nids, int nid);
00272  * Looking at how to implement these handlers in the case of cipher support, if
00273  * the framework wants the EVP_CIPHER for 'nid', it will call;
00274  *   foo(e, &p_evp_cipher, NULL, nid);    (return zero for failure)
00275  * If the framework wants a list of supported 'nid's, it will call;
00276  *   foo(e, NULL, &p_nids, 0); (returns number of 'nids' or -1 for error)
00277  */
00278 /* Returns to a pointer to the array of supported cipher 'nid's. If the second
00279  * parameter is non-NULL it is set to the size of the returned array. */
00280 typedef int (*ENGINE_CIPHERS_PTR)(ENGINE *, const EVP_CIPHER **, const int **, int);
00281 typedef int (*ENGINE_DIGESTS_PTR)(ENGINE *, const EVP_MD **, const int **, int);
00282 
00283 /* STRUCTURE functions ... all of these functions deal with pointers to ENGINE
00284  * structures where the pointers have a "structural reference". This means that
00285  * their reference is to allowed access to the structure but it does not imply
00286  * that the structure is functional. To simply increment or decrement the
00287  * structural reference count, use ENGINE_by_id and ENGINE_free. NB: This is not
00288  * required when iterating using ENGINE_get_next as it will automatically
00289  * decrement the structural reference count of the "current" ENGINE and
00290  * increment the structural reference count of the ENGINE it returns (unless it
00291  * is NULL). */
00292 
00293 /* Get the first/last "ENGINE" type available. */
00294 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_first(void);
00295 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_last(void);
00296 /* Iterate to the next/previous "ENGINE" type (NULL = end of the list). */
00297 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_next(ENGINE *e);
00298 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_prev(ENGINE *e);
00299 /* Add another "ENGINE" type into the array. */
00300 int ENGINE_add(ENGINE *e);
00301 /* Remove an existing "ENGINE" type from the array. */
00302 int ENGINE_remove(ENGINE *e);
00303 /* Retrieve an engine from the list by its unique "id" value. */
00304 ENGINE *ENGINE_by_id(const char *id);
00305 /* Add all the built-in engines. */
00306 void ENGINE_load_openssl(void);
00307 void ENGINE_load_dynamic(void);
00308 void ENGINE_load_cswift(void);
00309 void ENGINE_load_chil(void);
00310 void ENGINE_load_atalla(void);
00311 void ENGINE_load_nuron(void);
00312 void ENGINE_load_ubsec(void);
00313 void ENGINE_load_aep(void);
00314 void ENGINE_load_sureware(void);
00315 void ENGINE_load_4758cca(void);
00316 void ENGINE_load_cryptodev(void);
00317 void ENGINE_load_builtin_engines(void);
00318 
00319 /* Get and set global flags (ENGINE_TABLE_FLAG_***) for the implementation
00320  * "registry" handling. */
00321 unsigned int ENGINE_get_table_flags(void);
00322 void ENGINE_set_table_flags(unsigned int flags);
00323 
00324 /* Manage registration of ENGINEs per "table". For each type, there are 3
00325  * functions;
00326  *   ENGINE_register_***(e) - registers the implementation from 'e' (if it has one)
00327  *   ENGINE_unregister_***(e) - unregister the implementation from 'e'
00328  *   ENGINE_register_all_***() - call ENGINE_register_***() for each 'e' in the list
00329  * Cleanup is automatically registered from each table when required, so
00330  * ENGINE_cleanup() will reverse any "register" operations. */
00331 
00332 int ENGINE_register_RSA(ENGINE *e);
00333 void ENGINE_unregister_RSA(ENGINE *e);
00334 void ENGINE_register_all_RSA(void);
00335 
00336 int ENGINE_register_DSA(ENGINE *e);
00337 void ENGINE_unregister_DSA(ENGINE *e);
00338 void ENGINE_register_all_DSA(void);
00339 
00340 int ENGINE_register_DH(ENGINE *e);
00341 void ENGINE_unregister_DH(ENGINE *e);
00342 void ENGINE_register_all_DH(void);
00343 
00344 int ENGINE_register_RAND(ENGINE *e);
00345 void ENGINE_unregister_RAND(ENGINE *e);
00346 void ENGINE_register_all_RAND(void);
00347 
00348 int ENGINE_register_ciphers(ENGINE *e);
00349 void ENGINE_unregister_ciphers(ENGINE *e);
00350 void ENGINE_register_all_ciphers(void);
00351 
00352 int ENGINE_register_digests(ENGINE *e);
00353 void ENGINE_unregister_digests(ENGINE *e);
00354 void ENGINE_register_all_digests(void);
00355 
00356 /* These functions register all support from the above categories. Note, use of
00357  * these functions can result in static linkage of code your application may not
00358  * need. If you only need a subset of functionality, consider using more
00359  * selective initialisation. */
00360 int ENGINE_register_complete(ENGINE *e);
00361 int ENGINE_register_all_complete(void);
00362 
00363 /* Send parametrised control commands to the engine. The possibilities to send
00364  * down an integer, a pointer to data or a function pointer are provided. Any of
00365  * the parameters may or may not be NULL, depending on the command number. In
00366  * actuality, this function only requires a structural (rather than functional)
00367  * reference to an engine, but many control commands may require the engine be
00368  * functional. The caller should be aware of trying commands that require an
00369  * operational ENGINE, and only use functional references in such situations. */
00370 int ENGINE_ctrl(ENGINE *e, int cmd, long i, void *p, void (*f)());
00371 
00372 /* This function tests if an ENGINE-specific command is usable as a "setting".
00373  * Eg. in an application's config file that gets processed through
00374  * ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string(). If this returns zero, it is not available to
00375  * ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string(), only ENGINE_ctrl(). */
00376 int ENGINE_cmd_is_executable(ENGINE *e, int cmd);
00377 
00378 /* This function works like ENGINE_ctrl() with the exception of taking a
00379  * command name instead of a command number, and can handle optional commands.
00380  * See the comment on ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string() for an explanation on how to
00381  * use the cmd_name and cmd_optional. */
00382 int ENGINE_ctrl_cmd(ENGINE *e, const char *cmd_name,
00383         long i, void *p, void (*f)(), int cmd_optional);
00384 
00385 /* This function passes a command-name and argument to an ENGINE. The cmd_name
00386  * is converted to a command number and the control command is called using
00387  * 'arg' as an argument (unless the ENGINE doesn't support such a command, in
00388  * which case no control command is called). The command is checked for input
00389  * flags, and if necessary the argument will be converted to a numeric value. If
00390  * cmd_optional is non-zero, then if the ENGINE doesn't support the given
00391  * cmd_name the return value will be success anyway. This function is intended
00392  * for applications to use so that users (or config files) can supply
00393  * engine-specific config data to the ENGINE at run-time to control behaviour of
00394  * specific engines. As such, it shouldn't be used for calling ENGINE_ctrl()
00395  * functions that return data, deal with binary data, or that are otherwise
00396  * supposed to be used directly through ENGINE_ctrl() in application code. Any
00397  * "return" data from an ENGINE_ctrl() operation in this function will be lost -
00398  * the return value is interpreted as failure if the return value is zero,
00399  * success otherwise, and this function returns a boolean value as a result. In
00400  * other words, vendors of 'ENGINE'-enabled devices should write ENGINE
00401  * implementations with parameterisations that work in this scheme, so that
00402  * compliant ENGINE-based applications can work consistently with the same
00403  * configuration for the same ENGINE-enabled devices, across applications. */
00404 int ENGINE_ctrl_cmd_string(ENGINE *e, const char *cmd_name, const char *arg,
00405                 int cmd_optional);
00406 
00407 /* These functions are useful for manufacturing new ENGINE structures. They
00408  * don't address reference counting at all - one uses them to populate an ENGINE
00409  * structure with personalised implementations of things prior to using it
00410  * directly or adding it to the builtin ENGINE list in OpenSSL. These are also
00411  * here so that the ENGINE structure doesn't have to be exposed and break binary
00412  * compatibility! */
00413 ENGINE *ENGINE_new(void);
00414 int ENGINE_free(ENGINE *e);
00415 int ENGINE_up_ref(ENGINE *e);
00416 int ENGINE_set_id(ENGINE *e, const char *id);
00417 int ENGINE_set_name(ENGINE *e, const char *name);
00418 int ENGINE_set_RSA(ENGINE *e, const RSA_METHOD *rsa_meth);
00419 int ENGINE_set_DSA(ENGINE *e, const DSA_METHOD *dsa_meth);
00420 int ENGINE_set_DH(ENGINE *e, const DH_METHOD *dh_meth);
00421 int ENGINE_set_RAND(ENGINE *e, const RAND_METHOD *rand_meth);
00422 int ENGINE_set_destroy_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR destroy_f);
00423 int ENGINE_set_init_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR init_f);
00424 int ENGINE_set_finish_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR finish_f);
00425 int ENGINE_set_ctrl_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_CTRL_FUNC_PTR ctrl_f);
00426 int ENGINE_set_load_privkey_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_LOAD_KEY_PTR loadpriv_f);
00427 int ENGINE_set_load_pubkey_function(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_LOAD_KEY_PTR loadpub_f);
00428 int ENGINE_set_ciphers(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_CIPHERS_PTR f);
00429 int ENGINE_set_digests(ENGINE *e, ENGINE_DIGESTS_PTR f);
00430 int ENGINE_set_flags(ENGINE *e, int flags);
00431 int ENGINE_set_cmd_defns(ENGINE *e, const ENGINE_CMD_DEFN *defns);
00432 /* These functions (and the "get" function lower down) allow control over any
00433  * per-structure ENGINE data. */
00434 int ENGINE_get_ex_new_index(long argl, void *argp, CRYPTO_EX_new *new_func,
00435         CRYPTO_EX_dup *dup_func, CRYPTO_EX_free *free_func);
00436 int ENGINE_set_ex_data(ENGINE *e, int idx, void *arg);
00437 
00438 /* This function cleans up anything that needs it. Eg. the ENGINE_add() function
00439  * automatically ensures the list cleanup function is registered to be called
00440  * from ENGINE_cleanup(). Similarly, all ENGINE_register_*** functions ensure
00441  * ENGINE_cleanup() will clean up after them. */
00442 void ENGINE_cleanup(void);
00443 
00444 /* These return values from within the ENGINE structure. These can be useful
00445  * with functional references as well as structural references - it depends
00446  * which you obtained. Using the result for functional purposes if you only
00447  * obtained a structural reference may be problematic! */
00448 const char *ENGINE_get_id(const ENGINE *e);
00449 const char *ENGINE_get_name(const ENGINE *e);
00450 const RSA_METHOD *ENGINE_get_RSA(const ENGINE *e);
00451 const DSA_METHOD *ENGINE_get_DSA(const ENGINE *e);
00452 const DH_METHOD *ENGINE_get_DH(const ENGINE *e);
00453 const RAND_METHOD *ENGINE_get_RAND(const ENGINE *e);
00454 ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR ENGINE_get_destroy_function(const ENGINE *e);
00455 ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR ENGINE_get_init_function(const ENGINE *e);
00456 ENGINE_GEN_INT_FUNC_PTR ENGINE_get_finish_function(const ENGINE *e);
00457 ENGINE_CTRL_FUNC_PTR ENGINE_get_ctrl_function(const ENGINE *e);
00458 ENGINE_LOAD_KEY_PTR ENGINE_get_load_privkey_function(const ENGINE *e);
00459 ENGINE_LOAD_KEY_PTR ENGINE_get_load_pubkey_function(const ENGINE *e);
00460 ENGINE_CIPHERS_PTR ENGINE_get_ciphers(const ENGINE *e);
00461 ENGINE_DIGESTS_PTR ENGINE_get_digests(const ENGINE *e);
00462 const EVP_CIPHER *ENGINE_get_cipher(ENGINE *e, int nid);
00463 const EVP_MD *ENGINE_get_digest(ENGINE *e, int nid);
00464 const ENGINE_CMD_DEFN *ENGINE_get_cmd_defns(const ENGINE *e);
00465 int ENGINE_get_flags(const ENGINE *e);
00466 void *ENGINE_get_ex_data(const ENGINE *e, int idx);
00467 
00468 /* FUNCTIONAL functions. These functions deal with ENGINE structures
00469  * that have (or will) be initialised for use. Broadly speaking, the
00470  * structural functions are useful for iterating the list of available
00471  * engine types, creating new engine types, and other "list" operations.
00472  * These functions actually deal with ENGINEs that are to be used. As
00473  * such these functions can fail (if applicable) when particular
00474  * engines are unavailable - eg. if a hardware accelerator is not
00475  * attached or not functioning correctly. Each ENGINE has 2 reference
00476  * counts; structural and functional. Every time a functional reference
00477  * is obtained or released, a corresponding structural reference is
00478  * automatically obtained or released too. */
00479 
00480 /* Initialise a engine type for use (or up its reference count if it's
00481  * already in use). This will fail if the engine is not currently
00482  * operational and cannot initialise. */
00483 int ENGINE_init(ENGINE *e);
00484 /* Free a functional reference to a engine type. This does not require
00485  * a corresponding call to ENGINE_free as it also releases a structural
00486  * reference. */
00487 int ENGINE_finish(ENGINE *e);
00488 
00489 /* The following functions handle keys that are stored in some secondary
00490  * location, handled by the engine.  The storage may be on a card or
00491  * whatever. */
00492 EVP_PKEY *ENGINE_load_private_key(ENGINE *e, const char *key_id,
00493     UI_METHOD *ui_method, void *callback_data);
00494 EVP_PKEY *ENGINE_load_public_key(ENGINE *e, const char *key_id,
00495     UI_METHOD *ui_method, void *callback_data);
00496 
00497 /* This returns a pointer for the current ENGINE structure that
00498  * is (by default) performing any RSA operations. The value returned
00499  * is an incremented reference, so it should be free'd (ENGINE_finish)
00500  * before it is discarded. */
00501 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_default_RSA(void);
00502 /* Same for the other "methods" */
00503 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_default_DSA(void);
00504 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_default_DH(void);
00505 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_default_RAND(void);
00506 /* These functions can be used to get a functional reference to perform
00507  * ciphering or digesting corresponding to "nid". */
00508 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_cipher_engine(int nid);
00509 ENGINE *ENGINE_get_digest_engine(int nid);
00510 
00511 /* This sets a new default ENGINE structure for performing RSA
00512  * operations. If the result is non-zero (success) then the ENGINE
00513  * structure will have had its reference count up'd so the caller
00514  * should still free their own reference 'e'. */
00515 int ENGINE_set_default_RSA(ENGINE *e);
00516 int ENGINE_set_default_string(ENGINE *e, const char *def_list);
00517 /* Same for the other "methods" */
00518 int ENGINE_set_default_DSA(ENGINE *e);
00519 int ENGINE_set_default_DH(ENGINE *e);
00520 int ENGINE_set_default_RAND(ENGINE *e);
00521 int ENGINE_set_default_ciphers(ENGINE *e);
00522 int ENGINE_set_default_digests(ENGINE *e);
00523 
00524 /* The combination "set" - the flags are bitwise "OR"d from the
00525  * ENGINE_METHOD_*** defines above. As with the "ENGINE_register_complete()"
00526  * function, this function can result in unnecessary static linkage. If your
00527  * application requires only specific functionality, consider using more
00528  * selective functions. */
00529 int ENGINE_set_default(ENGINE *e, unsigned int flags);

00536 /**************************/
00537 /* DYNAMIC ENGINE SUPPORT */
00538 /**************************/
00539 
00540 /* Binary/behaviour compatibility levels */
00541 #define OSSL_DYNAMIC_VERSION        (unsigned long)0x00010200
00542 /* Binary versions older than this are too old for us (whether we're a loader or
00543  * a loadee) */
00544 #define OSSL_DYNAMIC_OLDEST     (unsigned long)0x00010200
00545 
00546 /* When compiling an ENGINE entirely as an external shared library, loadable by
00547  * the "dynamic" ENGINE, these types are needed. The 'dynamic_fns' structure
00548  * type provides the calling application's (or library's) error functionality
00549  * and memory management function pointers to the loaded library. These should
00550  * be used/set in the loaded library code so that the loading application's
00551  * 'state' will be used/changed in all operations. */
00552 typedef void *(*dyn_MEM_malloc_cb)(size_t);
00553 typedef void *(*dyn_MEM_realloc_cb)(void *, size_t);
00554 typedef void (*dyn_MEM_free_cb)(void *);
00555 typedef struct st_dynamic_MEM_fns {
00556     dyn_MEM_malloc_cb           malloc_cb;
00557     dyn_MEM_realloc_cb          realloc_cb;
00558     dyn_MEM_free_cb             free_cb;
00559     } dynamic_MEM_fns;
00560 /* FIXME: Perhaps the memory and locking code (crypto.h) should declare and use
00561  * these types so we (and any other dependant code) can simplify a bit?? */
00562 typedef void (*dyn_lock_locking_cb)(int,int,const char *,int);
00563 typedef int (*dyn_lock_add_lock_cb)(int*,int,int,const char *,int);
00564 typedef struct CRYPTO_dynlock_value *(*dyn_dynlock_create_cb)(
00565                         const char *,int);
00566 typedef void (*dyn_dynlock_lock_cb)(int,struct CRYPTO_dynlock_value *,
00567                         const char *,int);
00568 typedef void (*dyn_dynlock_destroy_cb)(struct CRYPTO_dynlock_value *,
00569                         const char *,int);
00570 typedef struct st_dynamic_LOCK_fns {
00571     dyn_lock_locking_cb         lock_locking_cb;
00572     dyn_lock_add_lock_cb            lock_add_lock_cb;
00573     dyn_dynlock_create_cb           dynlock_create_cb;
00574     dyn_dynlock_lock_cb         dynlock_lock_cb;
00575     dyn_dynlock_destroy_cb          dynlock_destroy_cb;
00576     } dynamic_LOCK_fns;
00577 /* The top-level structure */
00578 typedef struct st_dynamic_fns {
00579     const ERR_FNS               *err_fns;
00580     const CRYPTO_EX_DATA_IMPL       *ex_data_fns;
00581     dynamic_MEM_fns             mem_fns;
00582     dynamic_LOCK_fns            lock_fns;
00583     } dynamic_fns;
00584 
00585 /* The version checking function should be of this prototype. NB: The
00586  * ossl_version value passed in is the OSSL_DYNAMIC_VERSION of the loading code.
00587  * If this function returns zero, it indicates a (potential) version
00588  * incompatibility and the loaded library doesn't believe it can proceed.
00589  * Otherwise, the returned value is the (latest) version supported by the
00590  * loading library. The loader may still decide that the loaded code's version
00591  * is unsatisfactory and could veto the load. The function is expected to
00592  * be implemented with the symbol name "v_check", and a default implementation
00593  * can be fully instantiated with IMPLEMENT_DYNAMIC_CHECK_FN(). */
00594 typedef unsigned long (*dynamic_v_check_fn)(unsigned long ossl_version);
00595 #define IMPLEMENT_DYNAMIC_CHECK_FN() \
00596     unsigned long v_check(unsigned long v) { \
00597         if(v >= OSSL_DYNAMIC_OLDEST) return OSSL_DYNAMIC_VERSION; \
00598         return 0; }
00599 
00600 /* This function is passed the ENGINE structure to initialise with its own
00601  * function and command settings. It should not adjust the structural or
00602  * functional reference counts. If this function returns zero, (a) the load will
00603  * be aborted, (b) the previous ENGINE state will be memcpy'd back onto the
00604  * structure, and (c) the shared library will be unloaded. So implementations
00605  * should do their own internal cleanup in failure circumstances otherwise they
00606  * could leak. The 'id' parameter, if non-NULL, represents the ENGINE id that
00607  * the loader is looking for. If this is NULL, the shared library can choose to
00608  * return failure or to initialise a 'default' ENGINE. If non-NULL, the shared
00609  * library must initialise only an ENGINE matching the passed 'id'. The function
00610  * is expected to be implemented with the symbol name "bind_engine". A standard
00611  * implementation can be instantiated with IMPLEMENT_DYNAMIC_BIND_FN(fn) where
00612  * the parameter 'fn' is a callback function that populates the ENGINE structure
00613  * and returns an int value (zero for failure). 'fn' should have prototype;
00614  *    [static] int fn(ENGINE *e, const char *id); */
00615 typedef int (*dynamic_bind_engine)(ENGINE *e, const char *id,
00616                 const dynamic_fns *fns);
00617 #define IMPLEMENT_DYNAMIC_BIND_FN(fn) \
00618     int bind_engine(ENGINE *e, const char *id, const dynamic_fns *fns) { \
00619         if (ERR_get_implementation() != fns->err_fns) \
00620             { \
00621             if(!CRYPTO_set_mem_functions(fns->mem_fns.malloc_cb, \
00622                 fns->mem_fns.realloc_cb, fns->mem_fns.free_cb)) \
00623                 return 0; \
00624             CRYPTO_set_locking_callback(fns->lock_fns.lock_locking_cb); \
00625             CRYPTO_set_add_lock_callback(fns->lock_fns.lock_add_lock_cb); \
00626             CRYPTO_set_dynlock_create_callback(fns->lock_fns.dynlock_create_cb); \
00627             CRYPTO_set_dynlock_lock_callback(fns->lock_fns.dynlock_lock_cb); \
00628             CRYPTO_set_dynlock_destroy_callback(fns->lock_fns.dynlock_destroy_cb); \
00629             if(!CRYPTO_set_ex_data_implementation(fns->ex_data_fns)) \
00630                 return 0; \
00631             if(!ERR_set_implementation(fns->err_fns)) return 0; \
00632             } \
00633         if(!fn(e,id)) return 0; \
00634         return 1; }
00635 
00636 #if defined(__OpenBSD__) || defined(__FreeBSD__)
00637 void ENGINE_setup_bsd_cryptodev(void);
00638 #endif
